greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Second least-significant bit in the binary expansion of the n-th prime.
comment: a(n)=1 iff prime(n) is a member of A045326 (equivalently for n>1, iff prime(n)-3 is divisible by 4).
link: Amiram Eldar, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Fermat's 4n Plus 1 Theorem.
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Gaussian Prime.
formula: a(n) = 1-A098033(n), n>1. - Steven G. Johnson (stevenj(AT)math.mit.edu), Sep 18 2008
example: a(2)=1 because prime(2)=11_2 (in binary; decimal = 3_10) and its 2^1 bit is 1.
a(3)=0 because prime(3)=101_2 (in binary; decimal = 5_10) and its 2^1 bit is 0.
maple: seq(((ithprime(n)-2) mod 4) mod 3, n= 1 ..300); # _Gary Detlefs_, Dec 06 2011
results.author: Joseph Biberstine (jrbibers(AT)indiana.edu), Dec 06 2004
